title: Judd Apatow webchat â as it happened | Film | The Guardian
summary: `` anything can be funny if your intentions are good and your heart is in the right place ''
`` being there is a perfect movie . it could n't be more original , it 's hilarious and powerful , it is a miracle it even exists ''
`` i probably root for people to make their relationships work ''
`` every movie is an experiment [ ] . i have felt more like an indie rock band ''
`` i really do n't like joke-jokes , and ca n't remember even one ''
`` for the most part i think dramas are easier to make , because they are just comedies without the jokes ''

documents.title: that 's it for today !
text: thank you to everyone who posted questions , and huge thanks to judd for joining us today .
until next time !
guardian contributor juddapatow 10 august 2015 1:02pm thank you for all of your questions .
i hope i just changed your life .
i will accept nothing less .

documents.title: `` being there is a perfect movie . it could n't be more original , it 's hilarious and powerful , it is a miracle it even exists ''
text: davemitch1965 asks : what is your favourite movie of all time ?
guardian contributor juddapatow 10 august 2015 1:02pm i have a lot of favourite movies .
terms of endearment , harold and maude , almost famous , diner , borat .
but if i had to just one , i would probably say the hal ashby-peter sellers movie , being there .
it is a perfect movie .
it could n't be more original , it 's hilarious and powerful , it is a miracle it even exists .

documents.title: `` i probably root for people to make their relationships work ''
text: tystnaden asks : your films tend to have fairly conservative endings , in which bad behaviour is curbed in favour of traditional relationships , with personal growth represented as becoming part of a couple .
does this accurately represent your view of the world ?
guardian contributor juddapatow 10 august 2015 1:00pm as a child of divorce i probably root for people to make their relationships work .

i guess i could make movies about people who end up sad and alone or alone and thrilled , and maybe i will one day , but usually i root for people to make human connections and find happiness in a somewhat healthy relationship .
i do n't see that as a conservative value .
i just like to be hopeful .

documents.title: `` every movie is an experiment [ ] . i have felt more like an indie rock band ''
text: patrick shea moynahan asks : one of my favorite quotes is one by orson welles .
in his earlier years he was asked , what scares you the most ?
he answered , that they 'll figure out i have no idea what i 'm doing .
starting out on projects like freaks and geeks i can assume you too may have felt like this , as we all do early on in our career .
even though you are now a seasoned director do you ever have moments of fear and doubt when working on any of your newer projects ?
does being successful many times over curb these feelings at all ?
what is your process to work through such issues ?
guardian contributor juddapatow 10 august 2015 12:53pm every joke and every movie is an experiment , so you never know if it 's going to work .
i 've always liked what i 'm working on but there have been times when i thought that there were only a small percentage of people who would agree with me .
i felt more like an indie rock band .
i 'm always happy when something does really well , but a lot of the things i like are n't very popular so i will think about to heal my wounds when nobody shows up .
theythinkitsallover asks : when watching your films it feels like there 's a lot of ad libing by your main cast .
is that actually the case , that you just let them loose on some takes , within the given context , and see what you end up with ?
i 'm particularly thinking of seth rogen and steve carrell .

guardian contributor juddapatow 10 august 2015 12:51pm after we shoot the scene as scripted , i always like to let the actors and actresses play , because a fair amount of time they 'll come up with something way funnier than what 's in the script .
it seems crazy not to give them that opportunity .

documents.title: `` i really do n't like joke-jokes , and ca n't remember even one ''
text: abatha26 asks : what 's your favourite joke ?
guardian contributor juddapatow 10 august 2015 12:50pm the odd thing is i really do n't like joke-jokes , and ca n't remember even one .

helly worsdell asks : i really loved trainwreck however , i am increasingly disturbed by the unrealistic wearing of bras during love making scenes i hope you were making a point with amy 's bra and john cena 's ( scary ) full frontal does this irritate the film world as much as viewers it just looks really wrong can surely only be a matter of time before single beds make a come back in bedrooms of the film world guardian contributor juddapatow 10 august 2015 12:49pm next time i make a movie i 'm going to make you come to the set and plead the case .
but to be honest when i have sex , i 'm usually wearing a bra .
haigin88 asks : the larry sanders show : could you nominate your all-time favourite episode of the show ?
also , i 've read that burt reynolds was n't the easiest guest star but who was the guest who was the best to work with ?

guardian contributor juddapatow 10 august 2015 12:48pm all of the guests on the larry sanders show were pretty amazing , but ones that stand out include chris farley , who was probably the funniest of everybody .

warren zevon came on and played the french inhaler , which blew our minds ; i got to write a scene for alec baldwin which was a career highlight ; i co-wrote an episode that ellen starred in and she was as funny as you can be and an incredible actress .

once elvis costello starred in an episode , and during rehearsals he started playing alison for a bunch of the writers , and in the middle garry walked up and asked him a question , and he stopped singing .
i have never forgiven garry .
robertdale asks : where do you get your ideas from ?
guardian contributor juddapatow 10 august 2015 12:45pm i am not sure .
right now i 'm waiting for a movie idea to strike me .
i guess if i wait long enough , one day i 'll be in the shower , applying one of my many creams and lotions , and it 'll just occur to me .
clarity1251 asks : i 'd disagree slightly with an earlier commenter about your development of female characters and trainwreck being new .
lindsay from freaks and geeks was such an awesome influence on this impressionable 12-year-old when it first debuted .
still is .
any plans to revisit the weirs ?
if not , where do you think they 'd be now in 2015 ( or rather 1995 ) ?
guardian contributor juddapatow 10 august 2015 12:44pm we do n't have any plans to make any more freaks and geeks episodes .
i do n't think we could afford our cast at this point , and most of those characters are probably dead or in jail .
paul feig and i feel that it evolved into a perfect little miniseries , and we do n't want to force the world to see how james franco 's character wound up in a supermax prison .
tommyds asks : were you disappointed with the box-office performance of funny people ?
was it a hard film to market ?
i love the film and think that , although it has a wistful tone , it 's hilarious .

guardian contributor juddapatow 10 august 2015 12:43pm i always hope that a film i 've made will make a lot of money , but what 's more important is that as time goes by a lot of people get to see it and get something out of it .
i always knew that the themes of the movie would make it a little less mainstream , but i 'm really glad i got the chance to express those ideas , and work with my friend adam sandler .
as time goes by most people forget the box office of movies , and they just decide if they like it or not .
none of that really matters when you 're sitting home alone watching a movie in your underwear .
supermanhatescomics asks : theres been a dearth of real top qaulity american comedies ( since 2005 ) , why is that ?
guardian contributor juddapatow 10 august 2015 12:40pm i actually believe the opposite is true .
i think we are in a golden era .
and why is 2005 your dividing line ?
did something happen to you in 2005 ?
did the world change in 2005 ?
akashanu asks : is there any single message that you try to consistently convey throughout your films ?
guardian contributor juddapatow 10 august 2015 12:39pm `` do n't be a dick . ''
beavisonfire asks : have you ever been told that you bear a striking resemblance to tom green ?
guardian contributor juddapatow 10 august 2015 12:38pm that is one of the few statements that is an insult to both tom green and myself .
ozmogwai asks : would you ever consider doing something semi-autobiographical ?
guardian contributor juddapatow 10 august 2015 12:37pm let me think about it .
and further : would you ever consider taking drugs ?
guardian contributor juddapatow 10 august 2015 12:38pm those days are behind me .
i no longer trust that my mind wo n't turn on me .
philibuster asks : hi judd , could you name your top 5 comedy movies or shows of the last few years ?
guardian contributor juddapatow 10 august 2015 12:37pm my favourite tv show was mad men .
i also love the americans , the bachelor , the bachelorette , and broadchurch , and happy valley , and the fall .
wait , those are n't comedies !
i generally prefer documentaries , there 's a great new one called call me lucky that bob goldthwaite made about the comedian barry crimmins .
i also enjoyed the film amy , which wrecked me .
philibuster asks : hi judd , if you had one piece of advice for new comedy writers ?
guardian contributor juddapatow 10 august 2015 12:34pm i just put out a book called sick in the head which consists of interviews i 've done with comedians over the last 30 years .
i talk to people like jerry seinfeld , mike nichols , mel brooks , harold ramis , and more than 30 others - every bit of advice i 'd wished i 'd have gotten is in that book .
and all the money goes to charity .
thefuturesgreen asks : why should private banks be able to create money , when the boe could do the same thing ?
this would stop banks hiding bad debt off balance sheet .
97 % of uk money is bank-created credit money , this has caused inflation in house prices , leading to an unbalanced economy .
goods and services have not been inflated , because they are non speculative .
guardian contributor juddapatow 10 august 2015 12:32pm i am not sure what you mean .
but your question makes me want to become a survivalist , and move to the woods , and protect my barrels of water and food with small and large weaponry .
ipsitab asks : what do you do when you get stuck on a screenplay/story ?
have you ever left a screenplay incomplete ?
should we persist with story ideas and concepts to the hilt , or some are just not adaptable to the screen ?
what would you recommend for aspiring screenwriters , in terms of resources and tools that one can tap ?
guardian contributor juddapatow 10 august 2015 12:31pm there 's only one tool - you need to sit at a computer and write , a lot .
and as soon as you finish a screenplay , do n't talk about it for half a decade , just start another one .
the more you write , the better you 'll get .
lebomo asks : i do like your work but do you not feel that a 2hr+ comedy is the very definition of self-indulgent ?
do you struggle to edit your work ?
guardian contributor juddapatow 10 august 2015 12:30pm sometimes people say that , and then they 'll go home and watch 11 episodes of breaking bad in a row .
i just want eight more minutes .

documents.title: `` for the most part i think dramas are easier to make , because they are just comedies without the jokes ''
text: timothy thermann asks : how do you deal with movie critics ?
how can you tell whether a critic is being genuine or just trying to seem high-brow ?
are there some critics whom you respect more than others ?
thanks for doing this .
guardian contributor juddapatow 10 august 2015 12:29pm there are certain critics who have been very helpful to me in the past .
generally , i get the sense that certain critics do n't really enjoy comedy as much as they enjoy something filled with more pain and gravitas .
someone who is obsessed with the french new wave may not be the best person to review pineapple express - maybe we should have movie specialists who only review the types of movies that they like .
when a comedy works it feels effortless and becomes easy to dismiss as opposed to something about a great human tragedy which reeks of hard work .
for the most part i think dramas are easier to make , because they are just comedies without the jokes .
alec71 asks : judd , your films make fun of all walks of live .
though you then had a big problem with ricky gervais teasing actors .
why was that ?
or did you just see it as a opportune moment to get in the good books of some hollywood bigwigs ?
guardian contributor juddapatow 10 august 2015 12:25pm i 'm a huge ricky gervais fan .
i made fun of his golden globes monologue because i 'm not a fan of jokes which say someone is untalented or they have n't had a hit in a really long time .
so i did a line for line response to that particular monologue , just as a goof because someone had to come to cher 's defence .
that being said , i do n't think anything has made me laugh harder or more consistently than extras .

documents.title: `` the best way to become a director is to just say you are a director . just say that 's your job , and make something ''
text: liam quane asks : do you have any directorial advice ?
: ~ ) guardian contributor juddapatow 10 august 2015 12:21pm the best way to become a director is to just say you are a director .
there are no degrees which make you official , so just say that 's your job , and make something .
and further : what do you look for in the films you produce ?
guardian contributor juddapatow 10 august 2015 12:22pm usually it is about finding someone who i want to see in a movie .
sometimes i 'll see an actor or actress and think : i wish they starred in a movie !
and i realised that if i want to see that movie , i 'll have to make that movie .

documents.title: `` anything can be funny if your intentions are good and your heart is in the right place ''
text: thedailybumbler asks : what subject matters are hard to extract comedy from ?
guardian contributor juddapatow 10 august 2015 12:20pm anything can be funny if your intentions are good and your heart is in the right place .
the world can be awful and sometimes the only weapon we have is to laugh at it .
davide zicca asks : the marvel and the dc universe are gathering a lot of directors for their films .
i mean who would have thought that the troma director james gunn would direct guardians of the galaxy someday .
my question : is there any possible hero/comic book film you would to direct ?
which one would it be and how would you do it ?
p.s .
just one last question : when was the last time you watched a film in a cinema ?
and which one was it ?
guardian contributor juddapatow 10 august 2015 12:19pm the silver surfer - i would cast myself as the silver surfer , just as a way to motivate myself to lose weight .
the last film i saw at the cinema was the end of the tour , starring jason segal as david foster wallace - it was my favourite film of the year .
it was great to watch a movie that was about people and ideas .

documents.title: judd is with us now
text: here he is at guardian towers : beaumont-thomas

documents.title: post your questions for judd apatow
text: like a teddy bear with a penis .
this is how judd apatow is memorably described by amy schumer , the latest in a long line of comic talents to work with him .

he directs her in trainwreck , the story of a sexually confident , commitment-resistant journalist who falls for a sports doctor she 's writing about another in his series of films about people searching for meaning in the middle classes .
take knocked up , where seth rogen finds direction out of a cloud of weed smoke thanks to an unexpected pregnancy , or this is 40 , where a couple hit a midlife crisis hard .

then there 's the 40-year-old virgin , funny people , and his beloved teen tv drama freaks and geeks ; as a producer he 's shepherded girls to pop-cultural dominance , as well as making hits out of bridesmaids , pineapple express and superbad .
throughout it all he 's been vocal and far from vanilla , whether it 's defending lena dunham or attacking bill cosby .
with trainwreck released on august 14 , judd is joining us to answer your questions about the film and the rest of his career , from noon bst onward on monday 10 august .
post them in the comments below , and he 'll answer as many as possible .

bulletin.text: The director of Knocked Up, This Is 40 and now Trainwreck joined us to answer your questions and opened up about everything, from the future of Freaks and Geeks to his favourite comedies.
